meanings: To Be Back In Working Order

examples.en: I think the internet router will be fixed soon.
examples.ja: もうすぐ、インターネットのルーターが直ると思う。

examples.en: The bleeding stopped and the pain in the ankle went away.
examples.ja: 出血が止まって、足首のいたみも直った。

examples.en: If the toilet doesn't get fixed today, there is nothing we can do.
examples.ja: 今日トイレが直らないと仕方がない。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 直す means "to fix," where someone actively does the fixing. Well, 直る puts the focus on the thing getting fixed, so it means <vocabulary>to be fixed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be back in working order</vocabulary>.

In other words, don't use it to say "I fixed it," but do use it to say "It's fixed!" or "It's back to normal!" To remember this, imagine a British person excitedly shouting, "My loo (る) was broken, but now it's fixed!”
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with 直す, but here's a mnemonic in case you forgot:

Something needs <vocabulary>to be fixed</vocabulary> <reading>now</reading> (なお)! Seriously, it's urgent! You need this thing <vocabulary>to be back in working order</vocabulary> right now!

examples.en: A house with yellow on the west side is said to bring good luck for money.
examples.ja: 家の西側に黄色いものがあると金運がアップするそうです。

examples.en: A large poplar tree is planted on the west side of this hotel.
examples.ja: このホテルの西側には、大きなポプラの木が植えられていています。

examples.en: That's news from the western media, right?
examples.ja: それって西側のメディアのニュースでしょ？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>west</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> of something is known as the <vocabulary>west</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>west side</vocabulary>. Sorry, I couldn't think of a good west side story for this mnemonic.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses kun'yomi readings, both of which you happened to learn with the kanji. If you can remember these are kun'yomi here, you'll be good to go!

examples.en: It has a very elegant taste.
examples.ja: とても上品な味です。

examples.en: Kanae always uses a fork and knife elegantly.
examples.ja: カナエはいつも上品にナイフとフォークを使う。

examples.en: My friend gave a speech with elegant language at a Mrs. contest.
examples.ja: 私の友達はミセスコンテストで上品な言葉づかいでスピーチした。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 下品 is "crude" and "vulgar" - this is obviously the opposite. This is <vocabulary>elegant</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please teach me Osaka dialect.
examples.ja: 大阪弁を教えてください。

examples.en: My boyfriend speaks Osaka dialect.
examples.ja: 私の彼氏は大阪弁をしゃべります。

examples.en: When I arrived at Kansai Airport, I heard the Osaka dialect, and I felt relieved, thinking, "Ah, I've safely returned to Osaka."
examples.ja: 関西空港に着くと、大阪弁が聞こえてきて、「ああ、無事に大阪に帰ってきたんだなー」と思ってホッとしました。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 大阪 (Osaka)? This is the <kanji>dialect</kanji> they speak, making this word <vocabulary>Osaka dialect</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If you know how to read 大阪 you can just add 弁 to it and be able to read the whole thing, though maybe not in <vocabulary>Osaka dialect</vocabulary>. Okay, fine, it's probably the same thing in Osaka dialect.

examples.en: I can speak Kansai dialect.
examples.ja: 私は関西弁がしゃべれます。

examples.en: What does that sound like in the intonation of Kansai dialect?
examples.ja: それは関西弁のイントネーションではどんな感じになりますか？

examples.en: Huh, why can you speak in Kansai dialect? And it's a super thick Kansai dialect at that!
examples.ja: え、なんで関西弁話せるん？しかもめっちゃコテコテの関西弁やん！

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember 関西, the Kansai region of Japan? Well, they have their own <kanji>dialect</kanji> — the <vocabulary>Kansai dialect</vocabulary>.

関西弁 can actually refer to any number of local dialects from the Kansai region. There are lots of them (Osaka, Kyoto, and Nara dialects to name a few), all with little differences in pronunciation and vocabulary that separate them from the standard Japanese you'd hear in Tokyo.
reading_mnemonic: This reading just combines the vocab 関西 with the kanji reading for 弁.

examples.en: I'm working on Saturday this week.
examples.ja: 今週は土曜日も仕事です。

examples.en: It looks like it will rain on Saturday.
examples.ja: 土曜日は雨みたいですね。

examples.en: Are you going to the year-end party on Saturday?
examples.ja: 土曜日の忘年会、行く？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>earth</kanji> day of the week is a day you find yourself close to the earth. Either you found you drank too much on Friday, so on this day's morning you're laying right on the ground of earth. Or, maybe you just want to sleep in after staying up late on Friday. Either way, this day you lay close to the earth is <vocabulary>Saturday</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

examples.en: I have plans for next Sunday.
examples.ja: 来週の日曜日は予定があります。

examples.en: I go to church every Sunday morning.
examples.ja: 日曜日の朝は、毎週教会に行きます。

examples.en: I got sunburned during Sunday's hike.
examples.ja: 日曜日のハイキングで日焼けをしてしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>Sun</kanji> day of the week is <vocabulary>Sunday</vocabulary>. Doesn't get much easier than that for you. Lucky!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

examples.en: Would you like to go out for a drink this coming Monday after work?
examples.ja: 今度の月曜日、仕事の後、飲みに行かない？

examples.en: Monday is the beginning of a new week.
examples.ja: 月曜日は新しい週の始まりです。

examples.en: I always have a hard time getting up on Mondays. I don't want to go to work.
examples.ja: 月曜日はいつも起きるのがツライです。会社に行きたくないんで。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The "<kanji>moon</kanji>" day of the week is <vocabulary>monday</vocabulary>. Why? Because "Moon" is pretty much just "Mon," right?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

examples.en: I have piano lessons on Thursdays at six o'clock.
examples.ja: 木曜日は六時からピアノなんです。

examples.en: I am planning to do the cleanup on Thursday.
examples.ja: そうじは木曜日にしようと思ってます。

examples.en: I've been having coughs since Thursday.
examples.ja: 木曜日からセキが出てるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>tree</kanji> day of the week is <vocabulary>Thursday</vocabulary>. Tree day comes after water day (which is Wednesday, for Water-Wednesday!). Trees need water to grow, which is why the tree comes right after the water.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

examples.en: What we have to do on Wednesday can be roughly split up into three things.
examples.ja: 水曜日にするべきことは、大きく分けて三つあります。

examples.en: I'll get it done by Wednesday.
examples.ja: 水曜日までに終わらせます。

examples.en: Every Wednesday, I go to the pool after school and swim.
examples.ja: 毎週水曜日、学校の後プールに行って泳いでいます。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>water</kanji> day of the week is where the water flows from. Think of your entire week as a big hill, with Wednesday (hump day) being in the middle. This hump is a hill. What originates from hills? Water! That's why Water day is <vocabulary>Wednesday</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

examples.en: She is an international student from Canada.
examples.ja: 彼女はカナダからの留学生です。

examples.en: These are support programs available for exchange students.
examples.ja: これが留学生向けのサポートプログラムです。

examples.en: That class's foreign students look kind of innocent, don't you think?
examples.ja: あのクラスの留学生、何だかあどけない感じがするよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 留学, which means "study abroad"? Do you also remember 学生, which is "student"? This word is like those two words mashed together (they share a 学), making it a "study abroad student." What's a better way to say that? How about <vocabulary>exchange student</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I like Japanese comedy.
examples.ja: 私は日本のお笑いが好きです。

examples.en: We want to be comedians.
examples.ja: 俺たち、お笑い芸人になりたいんです。

examples.en: Oh, that was hilarious! I never expected it to end up like some kind of comedy!
examples.ja: あー、面白かった。まさかあんなお笑いみたいな結末になるとは、思ってもみなかったよ！

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 笑う is "to laugh." This is a noun version of that, though it's not "a laugh," (that's 笑い). Add お to that and you have the thing that makes you laugh. It's <vocabulary>comedy</vocabulary>. It's the <vocabulary>joke</vocabulary> that's elevated with お because it made you laugh SOOOOO much. Haha!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same 笑う or 笑い. It's also the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I try to put only what I need in my hand luggage.
examples.ja: 手荷物の中には、必要なものだけを入れるようにしています。

examples.en: You can leave your baggage at the front desk.
examples.ja: フロントで手荷物をあずかってもらえるよ。

examples.en: I got stuck at the baggage check!
examples.ja: 手荷物チェックのとこで引っかかっちゃったんだ！

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 荷物 and how it means "baggage" or "luggage." Add a <kanji>hand</kanji> to it and you have <vocabulary>hand baggage</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hand luggage</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If you know 荷物 and you know 手, then you should be able to Voltron the two together into one mega reading.

examples.en: Everybody laughed for some reason when I said that people eat KFC for Christmas dinner in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本ではクリスマスディナーにケンタッキーを食べると言ったら、なぜか笑いが起きました。

examples.en: I don't know what I'm laughing at anymore, but I just can't stop laughing.
examples.ja: もう自分でも何を笑ってるのか分からないけど、ただ笑いが止まらないんです。

examples.en: It’s not like you to cry at movies. You always laugh really hard when there are any serious scenes in them.
examples.ja: 映画を見て泣くなんて、お前らしくないじゃないか。いつもどの映画のどんなシリアスなシーンにも大笑いしてるのに。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 笑う is "to laugh." This is the noun version, because the う in 笑う turns to い (so don't confuse this as an adjective). What is the noun version of "to laugh"? It's <vocabulary>a laugh</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 笑う, so just make sure you know that so you can know this as well.

examples.en: If you write me an IOU, I don't mind loaning you some money.
examples.ja: ちゃんと借用書を書いてくれるんだったら、お金をかしてもいいよ。

examples.en: This illustration was borrowed from Aya of Tofugu.
examples.ja: このイラストはトーフグのアヤさんから借用させてもらいました。

examples.en: English has many loan words from French, and Spanish has many loan words from Arabic.
examples.ja: 英語にはフランス語からの借用語がたくさんありますし、スペイン語にはアラビア語からの借用語が多いんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>borrowing</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> is just another way to say <vocabulary>borrowing</vocabulary>. This is also for when you take out a <vocabulary>loan</vocabulary>.

借用 is a formal word for the borrowing of things like money, facilities, or other goods. You can also use it in a jokingly formal way in everyday conversation though, like ちょっと借用しただけだよ (I just borrowed it for a moment).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I want to skim the scum off the top, so can I borrow your ladle for a second?
examples.ja: アクを取りたいので、ちょっとお玉を借りてもいいですか？

examples.en: I borrowed one of your loose‐leaf sheets of paper, Kristen.
examples.ja: クリステンのルーズリーフ、一枚借りたよ。

examples.en: "I’m sorry I lost the romance novel I borrowed from you." "Don’t worry about it. I won’t need it anymore anyway. I have a girlfriend now."
examples.ja: 「ごめんね。君から借りていた恋愛小説をなくしちゃったんだ。」「気にしないでいいよ。それはもう必要ないから。彼女ができたんだ。」

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>borrow</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to borrow</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Dude, can I borrow your <reading>ca</reading>r (か)? Please?

examples.en: Before I knew it, my debt had reached five million yen.
examples.ja: 気づいたら借金が五百万円になっていた。

examples.en: Once he's paid off his debts, he plans to start a new life.
examples.ja: 借金を返し終わったら、彼は新しい人生を始めるつもりです。

examples.en: Koichi owes Viet 50,000,000 yen.
examples.ja: コウイチは、ビエトに五千万円を借金してます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>money</kanji> (and <kanji>gold</kanji>) you <kanji>borrow</kanji> is your <vocabulary>debt</vocabulary>. Be sure to pay it back before the yakuza come for you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The しゃく gets shortened to しゃっ though, so beware. Just think of that like the little bit that you lost to the yakuza, because they weren't happy you didn't pay back your debt. *cut*

examples.en: The cost benefit is greater with renting.
examples.ja: コストメリットは借家の方が大きいんですよ。

examples.en: You need to buy a house soon, too, or you'll be a renter for the rest of your life.
examples.ja: お前もそろそろ家を買わないと、一生借家ぐらしになるよ。

examples.en: I built a shed in the yard without permission, even though it's a rental property. I wonder if it's okay.
examples.ja: 借家なのに、庭に勝手に小屋を建てちゃったんですよね。大丈夫かな？

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>borrow</kanji> a <kanji>house</kanji> it's a <vocabulary>rented house</vocabulary>. This could also be a <vocabulary>house for rent</vocabulary>.

You can use 借家 in conversation to formally refer to a rented house or a house for rent. But it's more commonly found in legal contexts, like in laws and regulations.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but in this case the second kanji can be read with either the on'yomi or kun'yomi. This uses a less common kun'yomi of 家, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you live in a <vocabulary>rented house</vocabulary>, someone has to give you the keys and let you in and stuff. You're only renting, after all. And when they let you in they'll say, "Here's a <reading>shack</reading>, <reading>yah</reading> (しゃくや) house renter! Enjoy!"

By the way, in the secondary reading しゃっか, the しゃく changes to しゃっ. This reading is mostly used in legal contexts though, so しゃくや is more common.

examples.en: Nalanda Monastery was the Mecca of Buddhism.
examples.ja: ナーランダ僧院は仏教のメッカでした。

examples.en: I climbed up to the Taktsang Monastery on the mountain by myself.
examples.ja: 一人で山上のタクツァン僧院まで登りました。

examples.en: Nice to meet you, I'm Koichi. I am starting to work at this temple from today. Please take care of me.
examples.ja: 初めまして。今日からこの僧院で働くコウイチです。よろしくお願いします。

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>monk</kanji>’s <kanji>institution</kanji> is going to be a <vocabulary>monastery</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>temple</vocabulary>. What a nice place to live, I'm sure!

This word refers to Buddhist monasteries, and it's often used for ones outside of Japan.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This book is written by a former Buddhist monk.
examples.ja: この本は元仏僧の方が書かれた本です。

examples.en: I am currently researching the lifestyle of Buddhist monks.
examples.ja: 今、仏僧の生活スタイルについて調べています。

examples.en: It's quite a dangerous world when even a renowned Buddhist monk becomes a yakuza, isn't it?
examples.ja: 高名な仏僧がヤクザになるとは、世の中もブッソウになったモンだねぇ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>Buddha</kanji> <kanji>priest</kanji> is a <vocabulary>Buddhist Priest</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He always wants to complain about something.
examples.ja: 彼は何かにつけて文句を言いたがります。

examples.en: I could not complain about the food at that restaurant.
examples.ja: そのレストランの料理には文句のつけようがありませんでした。

examples.en: That's a pickup line, isn't it?
examples.ja: それは口説き文句でしょ？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>paragraph</kanji> in <kanji>writing</kanji> is what you send someone when you want to submit a <vocabulary>complaint</vocabulary>. You want to make sure these are in writing, though, otherwise you don't have proof of your complaint. Also, don't make it longer than a paragraph, because that's too long and nobody cares about how you think the shop staff mistreated your dog Fluffy.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Shh! That's a forbidden phrase!
examples.ja: シーッ！それは禁句ですよ！

examples.en: From now on, "Kawaii" is a forbidden phrase, okay?
examples.ja: これからは、「可愛い」は禁句ですよ。

examples.en: In front of our president, phrases like "next time" or "someday" are forbidden. He's a person who follows the policy of doing things today if they can be done today.
examples.ja: ウチの社長の前では「今度」とか「いつか」は禁句です。今日できることは今日やってしまうポリシーの人なんで。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>paragraph</kanji> that is under <kanji>prohibition</kanji> is under prohibition because it contains a <vocabulary>taboo word</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>taboo phrase</vocabulary>. Do not say this word, please!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Saki speaks in a cute voice, don't you think?
examples.ja: サキって可愛い声で話すよね。

examples.en: Who does that cute baby belong to?
examples.ja: あの可愛い赤ちゃんは誰の子ですか？

examples.en: This WaniKani icon is so cute!
examples.ja: このワニカニのアイコン、めっちゃ可愛い！

meaning_mnemonic: It's <kanji>possible</kanji> to <kanji>love</kanji> this thing. It's so gosh darn <vocabulary>cute</vocabulary>! Any really cute thing is possible to love.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is screwed up, though if we're lucky, you already know the word for cute. It seems to have injected itself into American and English culture a decent amount, anyways. If you are one of the lucky ones, you'll know that this word is read as かわいい. If you're not, think of the cute thing being a cow. Then you say, "that <reading>cowはいい</reading>" (かわいい), or "that cow is good" because it's so cute.

examples.en: We have permission from the school.
examples.ja: 学校から許可はもらっています。

examples.en: Who gave you permission to do that?
examples.ja: それって誰が許可したの？

examples.en: The president's permission is required to start a major project.
examples.ja: 大きなプロジェクトを開始するには、社長の許可が必要です。

meaning_mnemonic: I <kanji>permit</kanji> that it is <kanji>possible</kanji>. So, go ahead, do it. I give you <vocabulary>permission</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The theme of today's Tofugu podcast is the inseparability of life and death.
examples.ja: 今日のトーフグポッドキャストのテーマは、生と死の不可分性です。

examples.en: English contracts often have a severability clause as one of general provisions.
examples.ja: 英文けい約書には、一ぱんじょうこうの一つに、可分性というじょうこうがよくあります。

examples.en: As a general rule, divisible claims, like savings accounts, do not become the target of divisions of inherited property.
examples.ja: 預貯金などの可分債権は、原則として遺産分割の対象にはなりません。

meaning_mnemonic: When it's <kanji>possible</kanji> to <kanji>separate</kanji> something, it's <vocabulary>divisible</vocabulary>. Just imagine separating things into parts. It's possible. So, if that's possible, it's divisible. Now think of something that's nothing (i.e. "no candy bars"). That is not possible to separate into parts. That is not divisible.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Glasses are an integral part of my life.
examples.ja: メガネは私の生活に不可欠です。

examples.en: What do you think would be essential to becoming fluent in Japanese?
examples.ja: 日本語がペラペラになるのに不可欠なことは何だと思いますか？

examples.en: When I go to the beach, sunscreen is essential.
examples.ja: ビーチに行く時は、日焼け止めが不可欠です。

meaning_mnemonic: It's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>possible</kanji> to <kanji>lack</kanji>. It is <vocabulary> indispensable</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>essential</vocabulary>, so don't lack it!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I don't have the courage to confess.
examples.ja: 僕には告白する勇気はありません。

examples.en: How many times have you confessed your feelings to someone first?
examples.ja: 今までに何回自分から告白したことある？

examples.en: She finally confessed what she had done.
examples.ja: 彼女はついに自分のしたことを告白しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
To <kanji>announce</kanji> something and make it <kanji>white</kanji> is to make a <vocabulary>confession</vocabulary>. Think of a completely blank sheet of paper - your confession clears all the announcements from the sheet of paper, making it white.

This word is often used when someone confesses romantic feelings for someone else.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The mimosa flower heralds the arrival of spring.
examples.ja: ミモザは春を告げる花です。

examples.en: I bid farewell to my girlfriend.
examples.ja: 恋人に別れを告げました。

examples.en: That hurricane announced the end to our routine.
examples.ja: あのハリケーンで、私達の日常は終わりを告げた。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>announce</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to announce</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'd like <vocabulary>to announce</vocabulary>... we're not having one baby, we're having <reading>two</reading> (つ) babies!

examples.en: Did you see the newspaper ad in the Asahi Shimbun this morning?
examples.ja: 今朝の朝日新聞の新聞広告、見た？

examples.en: This chocolate was sold at a discount at Costco as a promotional item.
examples.ja: このチョコ、コストコで広告の品としてお安く売られてたんです。

examples.en: In a book I borrowed from the library, there was a grocery store advertisement stuck between the pages.
examples.ja: 図書館から借りた本に、スーパーの広告が一枚はさまっていました。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>announce</kanji> something to a <kanji>wide</kanji> audience, you're just throwing your message out there for everyone to hear. This is just a big wide <vocabulary>advertisement</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Sorry, you only learned the kun'yomi reading with 広. So, think of it this way when you need to remember this word's meaning: You're advertising something. It's a big <vocabulary>advertisement</vocabulary> to advertise how terrible a person <reading>こう</reading>いち is. Come up with some terrible things he's done so that you can imagine this crazy Koichi advertisement you made and ran on national TV.

examples.en: Did you see the preview for the next episode of that drama?
examples.ja: あのドラマの次回の予告、見た？

examples.en: The trailer for that movie often pops up on YouTube.
examples.ja: その映画の予告はYouTubeでよく流れてきます。

examples.en: A death threat was sent to Tofugu's office.
examples.ja: トーフグのオフィスに殺人予告が送られてきたんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>announce</kanji> something <kanji>beforehand</kanji> you will have <vocabulary>advance notice</vocabulary>. Advance notice is always nice to give.

You'll also see this used as an abbreviation of 予告編, meaning <vocabulary>trailer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>preview</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Maybe you should report it to the store manager.
examples.ja: 店長に報告した方がいいんじゃない？

examples.en: I have an announcement to make to you all today.
examples.ja: 今日は皆さんにご報告があります。

examples.en: You can leave when you have written your report.
examples.ja: 報告書が書けたら帰っていいですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>News</kanji> that you <kanji>announce</kanji> becomes a <vocabulary>report</vocabulary>. When someone announces news on a topic, they are giving you a report on the <vocabulary>information</vocabulary>.

報告 is a report given by someone after they've done some investigation or research into the topic. It can be used for class presentations on a topic or a report given to your boss. This differs from 報道, which is a report released by news organizations.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Smoking is not good for you.
examples.ja: 喫煙は体に良くないです。

examples.en: Is there a smoking room in this area?
examples.ja: この辺りに喫煙室はありますか？

examples.en: None of Tofugu's employees smoke.
examples.ja: トーフグの社員には、喫煙する人が一人もいません。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>consume</kanji> <kanji>smoke</kanji> you are <vocabulary>smoking</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I enjoy having the breakfast special at a cafe.
examples.ja: 私は喫茶店でモーニングを食べるのが好きです。

examples.en: The staff at this coffee shop are always smiling.
examples.ja: この喫茶店のスタッフは、いつも笑顔です。

examples.en: A stylish coffee shop has opened in our neighborhood.
examples.ja: ご近所にオシャレな喫茶店がオープンしました。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>consume</kanji> <kanji>tea</kanji> in a <kanji>shop</kanji>, it could either be a <vocabulary>cafe</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>tea house</vocabulary>, or slightly confusingly, a <vocabulary>coffee shop</vocabulary>. Welcome! Sit down. Relax. Have some tea (or coffee).

This word often refers to cafes with a retro feel to them, though they can be modern too. These places usually serve a variety of drinks and light meals.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are what you'd expect except for きつ getting shortened to きっ and 茶, which has this strange さ reading. To remember that it's さ instead of ちゃ, think of this <vocabulary>tea house</vocabulary> you're going in. You think it's nice and pleasant, and it is for a while... until someone starts working a <reading>saw</reading> (さ) outside, ruining the atmosphere. BEWWEEEEHHHEEEHHHHHE gatatatatatat BWEEEHEEE.

examples.en: Where is this information from?
examples.ja: その情報、どこ情報？

examples.en: First, let's organize the information.
examples.ja: まずは情報を整理しましょう。

examples.en: Sorry, I didn't have enough information.
examples.ja: すみません、情報不足でした。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>news</kanji> is that it should give you <vocabulary>information</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>data</vocabulary>, not fluff.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Rain is forecast for this afternoon.
examples.ja: 今日は午後から雨の予報です。

examples.en: Have you checked the weather forecast?
examples.ja: 天気予報、チェックした？

examples.en: The weather girl said the forecast is calling for hot weather, starting tomorrow.
examples.ja: お天気お姉さんは、明日から暑くなるって予報してたけどね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>news report</kanji> that covers things <kanji>beforehand</kanji> (before they happen) is a <vocabulary>forecast</vocabulary>. For example, a weather forecast is a 天気予報.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I cannot believe what the media reports.
examples.ja: メディアが報じることは信じられません。

examples.en: Only the Associated Press reported the news.
examples.ja: そのニュースを報じたのはAP通信のみでした。

examples.en: Everyone felt relieved when they reported that Koichi was safe.
examples.ja: コウイチの無事が報じられて、みんな胸をなで下ろしました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>news report</kanji> so you could try to say "to news report" but that doesn't make sense. What does make sense is "<vocabulary>to report on</vocabulary>," however.
reading_mnemonic: The reading doesn't seem like it's the kanji's on'yomi reading, but it is. What an oddity! Do you think it's worth doing a news report on it? Koichi, reporting in on this strange reading that is readable by you right now. Signing off.

examples.en: Don't report lies!
examples.ja: ウソを報道するな！

examples.en: How will this terrorist attack be reported in Japan?
examples.ja: 今回のテロのことは、日本ではどのように報道されていますか？

examples.en: According to local media reports, a rare trading card of WaniKani was sold at auction for one hundred million yen.
examples.ja: 地元メディアの報道によると、ワニカニのレアトレーディングカードがオークションで一億円で落札されたそうです。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>News</kanji> travels down the <kanji>road</kanji> by way of a <vocabulary>news report</vocabulary>.

報道 specifically refers to information put out by news organizations or the press in the form of newspaper articles, radio or television broadcasts, etc. Notice that it's different from 報告, which is more general and means the reporting of information by anyone.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Where did you buy this charm?
examples.ja: このお守り、どこで買ったの？

examples.en: I always keep a picture of my father in my wallet as a talisman.
examples.ja: 私はいつも父の写真をお守り代わりにサイフに入れています。

examples.en: Apparently, even God has compatibility, so it's not good to wear multiple charms at the same time.
examples.ja: 神様にも相性があるから、たくさんのお守りを同時に付けるのは、良くないんだって。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 守る is "to protect," right? This is like that, but it's the noun version. It's not really "a protection," though it kind of is. What things can you wear to protect you from things like bad luck, demons, and ancient aliens? That would be an <vocabulary>amulet</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>charm</vocabulary>. You'll see these kinds of things sold at temples and such.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is like that of 守る, so if you know the reading of that word you should be able to read this one as well.

examples.en: I took a housesitting job for 20,000 yen a day.
examples.ja: 一日二万円で留守番の仕事を引き受けた。

examples.en: In the U.S., it is not acceptable to leave small children alone at home.
examples.ja: アメリカでは小さい子どもだけで留守番させるのNGです。

examples.en: I called, but it was an answering machine!
examples.ja: かけたけど、留守番電話だった！

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 留守 means "absence" or "away from home"? Well, now that you're absent from your home, it's someone else's  turn to come to your home and take care of it. This person is the <vocabulary>caretaker</vocabulary>, someone who's <vocabulary>looking after one's house</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 留守 will be important as well.

examples.en: How can you sit seiza for that long?
examples.ja: 何でそんなに長い間正座できるの？

examples.en: Frankly, I am not good at sitting on my knees.
examples.ja: 正直、正座は苦手です。

examples.en: Since I knelt in seiza throughout the memorial service, my legs have become quite numb.
examples.ja: 法要の間ずっと正座をしていたので、足がすごくシビれています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>correct</kanji> way to <kanji>sit</kanji> is this way: <vocabulary>traditional Japanese sitting</vocabulary> (this is when you sit on your legs and your feet, kneeling). You can also call it <vocabulary>seiza</vocabulary>. Learning the reading will help with the meaning.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Have you ever done zazen?
examples.ja: 座禅を組んだことはありますか？

examples.en: That Italian soccer team always does zazen on the field before a game.
examples.ja: あのイタリアのサッカーチームは、いつも試合の前にグランドで座禅を組みます。

examples.en: She relaxes every morning in zazen.
examples.ja: 彼女は毎朝座禅を組んでリラックスします。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>sit</kanji> and do <kanji>zen</kanji> you are probably doing <vocabulary>zen meditation</vocabulary>. Hummmmm.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This seat's cushion is really comfy.
examples.ja: この座席のクッション、めっちゃいい感じ。

examples.en: I didn't know that I had to make reservations for seats.
examples.ja: 座席の予約が必要だったとは、知りませんでした。

examples.en: I found bed bugs on the train seat.
examples.ja: 電車の座席にトコジラミを見つけてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sit</kanji> <kanji>seat</kanji> is probably going to be a <vocabulary>seat</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am in Ginza now.
examples.ja: 今は銀座にいます。

examples.en: There are many bars in Ginza.
examples.ja: 銀座にはバーがたくさんあります。

examples.en: My friend works as a hostess in Ginza, Tokyo.
examples.ja: 私の友達は、東京の銀座でホステスをしています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>silver</kanji> <kanji>seat</kanji> isn't some crazy kingdom where the king sits upon a silver seat. It is a famous place in Tokyo. Perhaps if you read the reading it will become more apparent what the meaning is (since they're the same). This silver seat place is <vocabulary>Ginza</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I bought a station lunch at a kiosk.
examples.ja: キオスクで駅弁を買いました。

examples.en: I'm looking at ekiben at the Tokyo Station ekiben shop right now.
examples.ja: 今、東京駅の駅弁屋で駅弁を見ています。

examples.en: Popular ekiben are sold out by ten in the morning.
examples.ja: 人気の駅弁は、朝十時には売り切れてしまいます。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 弁当 is "bento"? Well, the 弁 in this word comes from that, so pretend it means "bento." Then, when you have a <kanji>train station</kanji> to go along with the bento, you have a <vocabulary>train station bento</vocabulary>. As you might think, a train station bento is just a bento that's sold at a train station. Easy!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We can't find Koichi's bow anywhere.
examples.ja: コウイチの弓がどこにも見当たらないんだ。

examples.en: You have to stabilize your upper body to draw the bow.
examples.ja: 弓を引くには、まず上半身を安定させなくてはいけません。

examples.en: I don't think you can buy bows and arrows at a convenience store, can you?
examples.ja: コンビニでは弓と矢は買えないと思うよ？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

All we need to shoot a <vocabulary>bow</vocabulary> is <reading>you 'n' me</reading> (ゆみ). One person holds the bow, the other fires the arrows. Teamwork makes the dream work. Even for shooting bows. Just you 'n' me.

examples.en: I took up Kyudo last month.
examples.ja: 先月、弓道を始めたんです。

examples.en: Why are Japanese bows for kyudo so powerful?
examples.ja: 日本の弓道の弓って、どうしてそんなに強いの？

examples.en: I got up early and went to the Kyudo club dojo to do Kyudo.
examples.ja: 早起きして、弓道部の道場で弓道をしてきました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>path</kanji> of the <kanji>bow</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>archery</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I almost forgot Koichi's face.
examples.ja: 危うくコウイチの顔を忘れる所だったよ。

examples.en: Sorry, Kanae. We all totally forgot about how much effort you put into it.
examples.ja: ごめんね、カナエちゃん。みんなカナエちゃんがどれだけ努力したのかすっかり忘れちゃってたんだ。

examples.en: Forget about it. There's nothing you can do about it now.
examples.ja: もう忘れなって。今さらどうにもならないんだから。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>forget</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to forget</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You don't want <vocabulary>to forget</vocabulary> anything, because forgetting always makes everything <reading>worse</reading> (わす). Forgot your car keys? Now you can't drive. Forgot someone's name? Now you have to ask again and it'll be awkward. All these situations make your day worse, and probably your life worse too.

examples.en: The year-end party is tomorrow, not today.
examples.ja: 忘年会は今日じゃなくて明日です。

examples.en: I'm already really forgetful, so I don't need a so-called "forget the year party."
examples.ja: 元々忘れっぽいんで、私には「忘年会」は必要ありません。

examples.en: As for what happened at today's year-end party, I'll just let it go.
examples.ja: 今日の忘年会であった出来事は、忘れる事にします。

meaning_mnemonic: Time to get <kanji>together</kanji> and <kanji>forget</kanji> the <kanji>year</kanji>... what a terrible year, good thing a new one is coming. This get together is a <vocabulary>year end party</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: In order to write a good article, it is important to make a rough draft.
examples.ja: いい記事を書くためには下書きをすることが大事です。

examples.en: For now, the rough draft of the illustration is complete.
examples.ja: イラストの下書きが完成しました。

examples.en: I always go for it without any drafts; I'm all about one-shot victories!
examples.ja: 俺はいつも下書き無しで、一発勝負なんだよ！

meaning_mnemonic: Something <kanji>below</kanji> your <kanji>writing</kanji> isn't what you want to necessarily publish to the world. It's below your writing, after all. This is merely a <vocabulary>rough draft</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading, as you can maybe guess from the hiragana sticking out. If you know the readings of the words 下 and 書く separately, you should be able to combine them into one reading. Just don't forget the rendaku here!

examples.en: I always try to put my schedule on the calendar as soon as it is made.
examples.ja: いつも予定ができたら、すぐにカレンダーに書き入れるようにしています。

examples.en: I think there should be more space for comments. The current space is not enough.
examples.ja: もっとコメントを書き入れるスペースがあった方がいいと思います。今のスペースだと足りないです。

examples.en: If you could fill in your social security number here in this document, I can take care of the rest.
examples.ja: この書類のここに社会保証番号を書き入れてもらえれば、あとは全て上手くやっておきますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>insert</kanji> what you <kanji>write</kanji> into something is <vocabulary>to write in</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fill in</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 書く and 入れる. Combine those two words to get the reading of this word.

examples.en: I can't remember how to write this kanji.
examples.ja: この漢字の書き方が思い出せません。

examples.en: Could you teach me how to write business e-mails?
examples.ja: ビジネスメールの書き方を教えてください。

examples.en: I think this way of writing makes it a little difficult to understand the meaning of the sentence.
examples.ja: この書き方だと、ちょっと文の意味が分かりにくいんじゃないかな。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the <kanji>way</kanji> of <kanji>writing</kanji> (kind of like how 見方 is the way of seeing). So this means <vocabulary>way to write</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>how to write</vocabulary>. How's your 書き方 for kanji? Mine is terrible.
reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 書く and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.

examples.en: Bacon is so tasty that I can eat an unlimited number of strips.
examples.ja: ベーコンは美味しいから、何枚でも食べれるよ。

examples.en: About how many tickets have you sold so far?
examples.ja: チケット、今のところ何枚ぐらい売れたの？

examples.en: How many WaniKani trading cards are there in total?
examples.ja: ワニカニのトレーディングカードって、全部で何枚あるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>flat object</kanji>s but <kanji>what</kanji> amount of flat objects? This word is asking that question: "<vocabulary>how many flat objects</vocabulary> are there?" If this doesn't make sense, think back to words like 何回 or 何年 which ask "how many ____" just like this one.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The minimum order quantity for stickers is one hundred.
examples.ja: ステッカーの注文枚数は、百枚からです。

examples.en: Can you guess how many credit cards Koichi has in his wallet at the moment?
examples.ja: 今コウイチのサイフの中にあるクレジットカードの枚数を当ててみてください。

examples.en: Could you count the number of origami papers?
examples.ja: 折り紙の枚数を数えてもらえますか？

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>flat object</kanji>s. You have a <kanji>number</kanji> of them. These flat objects are flat things, right? Flat things like sheets of paper, perhaps (or other sheets of things). So, this word is <vocabulary>number of sheets</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I’ll give you five stickers as a bonus too.
examples.ja: ステッカーを五枚、オマケに付けておきますね。

examples.en: There are only five sheets of copy paper left.
examples.ja: コピー用紙、あと五枚しかないよ。

examples.en: I went to a convenience store and bought five postcards.
examples.ja: コンビニに行って、葉書を五枚買いました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 枚 is a <kanji>flat objects counter</kanji>. So, now we're counting! You have <vocabulary>five flat objects</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Can I just wash it with water?
examples.ja: 水で洗うだけでいいの？

examples.en: When you return home, please wash your hands and gargle.
examples.ja: 家に帰ったら手を洗ってうがいをしてください。

examples.en: Viet made a clean break from both the yakuza world and drugs.
examples.ja: ビエトは、ヤクザの世界からも、薬物からも、完全に足を洗った。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wash</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to wash</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have <vocabulary>to wash</vocabulary> <reading>a ro</reading>ck (あら) you found. It looks shiny, but you can't tell until you wash it.

examples.en: While I waited for the car wash to finish, the part-timer kept yacking at me and it was really annoying.
examples.ja: 洗車が終わるのを待っている間、ガソリンスタンドのバイトがずっとダラダラ話しかけてきて、かなりウザかった。

examples.en: Who would buy a car wash business to launder money?
examples.ja: 誰がマネー・ロンダリングするのに洗車ビジネスなんて買うっていうのさ？

examples.en: If there's someone out there who wants to wash Koichi's car, please email us at hello@tofugu.com.
examples.ja: コウイチの車の洗車をしたいという方がいたら、hello@tofugu.comまでメールしてください。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>wash</kanji> that washes <kanji>car</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>car wash</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Don't confuse this with the same-sounding 戦車 though... unless you're washing your 戦車 in a 洗車...

examples.en: It's a tote bag with a simple and sophisticated design.
examples.ja: シンプルで洗練されたデザインのトートバッグです。

examples.en: Her use of language is very sophisticated.
examples.ja: 彼女の言葉づかいはとても洗練されています。

examples.en: Hmmm... not bad, but maybe a little more refinement would be good?
examples.ja: うーん…悪くはないけど、もう少し洗練した方がいいかな？

meaning_mnemonic: You take your <kanji>practice</kanji> and you <kanji>wash</kanji> it. Slowly chunks fall off and it becomes more and more simple. You are washing away the gunk on the outside to attain <vocabulary>refinement</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>polish</vocabulary> yourself, via practice.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am going to bake a cheesecake today.
examples.ja: 今日はチーズケーキを焼くつもりです。

examples.en: If you find these in your yard, burn them immediately. They're tick eggs.
examples.ja: これを庭で見つけたら、すぐに焼いてください。ダニのタマゴなんで。

examples.en: Isn't that meat already cooked? Let's move it to the plate before it becomes overcooked!
examples.ja: そのお肉、もう焼けてるんじゃない？焼きすぎになる前にお皿に上げよう！

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bake</kanji> or <kanji>burn</kanji>. So, the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to bake</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to burn something</vocabulary>, or even <vocabulary>to grill</vocabulary>.

焼く means to apply heat to something to change it in a physical way. It can refer to lightly toasting something, charring it, or even burning it to ashes depending on the context. It's commonly used in cooking contexts to describe baking, grilling, or roasting food. But it can also be used with pottery, film photography, and even sun-tanning.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: You should properly take care of your skin from sunburn.
examples.ja: ちゃんと日焼けケアした方がいいよ。

examples.en: I got suntanned from being on the beach too long.
examples.ja: ビーチにいすぎて日焼けしちゃった。

examples.en: Because I forgot to apply sunscreen, I got sunburnt and turned completely red.
examples.ja: 日焼け止めクリームを忘れたせいで、日焼けで真っ赤になった。

meaning_mnemonic: When the <kanji>sun</kanji> <kanji>burn</kanji>s something, and that something is you, it's giving you <vocabulary>sunburn</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings here are the vocab kun'yomi readings. You have ひ for 日 and や for 焼け (which you learned with the vocab). Combine it with some sunscreen and hopefully you'll prevent the <vocabulary>sunburn</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Do you want to go out for yakitori today?
examples.ja: 今日、焼き鳥食べに行かない？

examples.en: I started working part-time at a yakitori restaurant.
examples.ja: 焼き鳥屋でアルバイトを始めました。

examples.en: Grilled chicken is essential for my life.
examples.ja: 焼き鳥は私の生活に不可欠です。

meaning_mnemonic: A nicely <kanji>bake</kanji>d <kanji>bird</kanji> isn't just any bird, it's <vocabulary>grilled chicken</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>roast chicken</vocabulary>. You may also know it by its Japanese name: <vocabulary>yakitori</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings. With 焼き, you can use the reading you learned with the kanji. With 鳥 just remember back to the vocab word, とり. Combine and eat.

examples.en: I am in the mood for grilled meat today.
examples.ja: 今日は焼き肉が食べたい気分です。

examples.en: Yesterday, my family and I had yakiniku using a hot plate at home.
examples.ja: 昨日は家族でホットプレートで焼き肉をしました。

examples.en: I find it really irritating when people chew yakiniku loudly.
examples.ja: 私が特にイライラするのは、焼き肉をクチャクチャ音を立てて食べる人です。

meaning_mnemonic: Nicely <kanji>bake</kanji>d <kanji>meat</kanji> is <vocabulary>grilled meat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>yakiniku</vocabulary>. Mmm, yum! If you go to Japan look out for 焼肉 places (same meaning and reading). They're pretty tasty, if you're into meat at least.
reading_mnemonic: 焼き uses the reading you learned with the kanji. 肉 does too. Put them on the grill and enjoy!

examples.en: This is a photo of a sunset.
examples.ja: これは夕焼けの写真です。

examples.en: I booked a room with an ocean view where you can see the sunset.
examples.ja: 夕焼けが見えるオーシャンビューの部屋を予約しました。

examples.en: Watching the sunset calms my mind.
examples.ja: 夕焼けを見ると、心が落ち着きます。

meaning_mnemonic: When the <kanji>evening</kanji> is <kanji>burning</kanji> with sun, it is the sun going down, getting all close to the horizon and earth. This is the <vocabulary>sunset</vocabulary>, or more specifically, the <vocabulary>evening glow</vocabulary> you can see during a sunset.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. Combine 夕 and 焼け (you learned the reading via the kanji) and you'll have <reading>ゆうやけ</reading>.

examples.en: Hey! Smoke is coming out of the grill!!
examples.ja: ちょっと！バーベキューグリルから煙が出てるよ！！

examples.en: I woke up to the smell of burnt smoke.
examples.ja: 煙のコゲくさいニオイで起きました。

examples.en: The time of our youth vanished in the blink of an eye, like smoke.
examples.ja: 僕らの青春の時間は、煙のようにアッという間に消えていった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're standing around a <vocabulary>smoke</vocabulary> machine. It's billowing up smoke. Strangely, your buddy Bill Murray is here too. For some reason, he loves the smoke, and he puts his head in it, breathing it in deeply until he goes into a coughing fit. You decide it's time to stop him. "<reading>Kay, Murray</reading> (けむり), it's time to stop that," you say.

examples.en: I thought I saw black smoke, and turns out there's a fire at that apartment building over there!
examples.ja: 黒煙が見えると思ったら、あそこのマンションで火事だって！

examples.en: I like diesel cars that run with a cloud of black smoke.
examples.ja: 俺は黒煙をモクモク出して走るディーゼル車が好きなんです。

examples.en: The steam locomotive billowing black smoke and running through the winter landscape of Hokkaido was really cool.
examples.ja: 黒煙を上げながら冬の北海道を走るSLは、とてもカッコよかったです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Black</kanji> <kanji>smoke</kanji> is <vocabulary>black smoke</vocabulary>. It's also something you should avoid if you can.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is a non-smoking area.
examples.ja: ここは禁煙スペースです。

examples.en: All guest rooms at this hotel are non-smoking.
examples.ja: このホテルは、全客室禁煙です。

examples.en: I quit smoking using a smoking cessation patch.
examples.ja: 僕は禁煙パッチを使って禁煙しました。

meaning_mnemonic: If <kanji>smoke</kanji> is <kanji>prohibite</kanji>d you probably shouldn't smoke. Aka <vocabulary>no smoking</vocabulary>, okay?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Students are not allowed to work part-time at this school.
examples.ja: この学校では、学生のアルバイトは禁止されています。

examples.en: I believe pets are not allowed in this apartment.
examples.ja: このアパート、たしかペットは禁止だったはずですよ。

examples.en: Viet told his gangsters that gambling was forbidden.
examples.ja: ビエトは手下のヤクザたちに、ギャンブルは禁止だと言い聞かせた。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Stop</kanji>! That's <kanji>prohibition</kanji> (prohibited)! When something is prohibited and you're forced to stop, that thing is obviously <vocabulary>forbidden</vocabulary>. If you see this you should probably not do the thing it's telling you not to do.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What's the name of that Zen temple, again?
examples.ja: あの禅寺の名前は何だっけ？

examples.en: I visited Nanzenji temple in Kyoto.
examples.ja: 京都の南禅寺に行ってきました。

examples.en: This temple is a Zen temple built in the 14th century.
examples.ja: このお寺は、十四世紀に建てられた禅寺です。

examples.en: I like the Zen temple in Kyoto called Tōfuku-ji.
examples.ja: 東福寺っていう京都の禅寺が好きなんです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>zen</kanji> <kanji>temple</kanji> is just what it sounds like, a <vocabulary>zen temple</vocabulary>. Sounds nice.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the two words 禅 and 寺 put together. The てら gets changed to でら, though.

In terms of when it's pronounced ぜんじ, if you put this word onto the end of the name of a 禅寺 the pronunciation changes to ぜんじ. It makes sense - it's more like a jukugo word that way (not that the original isn't, but you can see the separation of words coming together which gives the hint that it's a kun'yomi combo reading). Anyways, you may need a zen temple to keep your mind pure enough to remember this, but it's a good thing to keep in mind if you can.

examples.en: He is a Zen priest.
examples.ja: 彼は禅僧です。

examples.en: That is what some Zen monk said.
examples.ja: それは、どこかの禅僧が言っていた言葉です。

examples.en: How can I become a Zen monk?
examples.ja: 禅僧になるには、どうすればいいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>Zen</kanji> <kanji>priest</kanji> is a <vocabulary>zen priest</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There's a wide variety of different races in this city.
examples.ja: この町には、色々な人種の人がいます。

examples.en: I don't really like racial jokes.
examples.ja: 人種をネタにしたジョークは、あんまり好きじゃありません。

examples.en: Now, race has nothing to do with it, does it?
examples.ja: 今、人種は関係ないですよね？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>kind</kanji> or <kanji>type</kanji> of <kanji>person</kanji> is when you categorize a person into different types. How do we do that? Well, you categorize by <vocabulary>race of people</vocabulary> (or more simply by <vocabulary>race</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That's almost as if you didn't do it.
examples.ja: それは、ほぼやってないに等しいんじゃない？

examples.en: Even for people who aren’t nerds, using uppercase letters on the internet is equivalent to shouting.
examples.ja: オタクだけではなく他の人にとっても、ネット上で大文字を使うことは大声を出すことに等しいですよ。

examples.en: Do you think the left and right balls are equal in weight?
examples.ja: 左の金玉と右の金玉の重さって等しいと思いますか？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>equal</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>equal</vocabulary> (and also <vocabulary>similar</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>equivalent</vocabulary>). That "similar" one is a bit weird, because "similar" is not equal, though I'd lean more towards equal.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What should be equal above all things? I think each <reading>人</reading> (ひと) should be equal!

examples.en: The "equal sign" is called "tōgō"! I didn't know that.
examples.ja: 「イコール」って「等号」って言うんだ！知らなかった。

examples.en: Koichi feels sick if the top and bottom lines of an equal sign are not the same length.
examples.ja: コウイチは等号の上と下の線が同じ長さじゃないと気分が悪くなる。

examples.en: You have to pay attention to whether the formula to the right of the equal sign is plus or minus.
examples.ja: 等号の右側の数式が正か負かについて、注意する必要があります。

meaning_mnemonic:
How do you represent an <kanji>equal</kanji> <kanji>number</kanji>? With an <vocabulary>equal sign</vocabulary>.

It's worth pointing out that this is a pretty formal word that's used in advanced math. In everyday conversation, people would use イコール for the equal sign.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: How much is the first prize for this lottery?
examples.ja: この宝くじの一等の賞金はいくらですか？

examples.en: I won this bacon keychain when I won first prize in the bacon costume competition.
examples.ja: このベーコンのキーホルダーは、私がベーコンのコスプレ大会で一等賞を取った時にもらったんです。

examples.en: You are in the first-class carriage, yeah? That's so like you, Koichi!
examples.ja: 一等車に乗ってるとは、さすがコウイチだね。

meaning_mnemonic: When you're <kanji>equal</kanji> to <kanji>one</kanji> you are the very top. You are <vocabulary>first class</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>first rank</vocabulary>. In fact, you are <vocabulary>the best</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち gets shortened to いっ though, so watch out for that if you want to remain <vocabulary>the best</vocabulary>, yeah?

examples.en: Military training for soldiers took place in England.
examples.ja: イギリスで兵士たちの軍事訓練が行われました。

examples.en: That dog is well trained.
examples.ja: あの犬はよく訓練されている。

examples.en: Don't worry, it will work if you follow the training.
examples.ja: 大丈夫、訓練どおりにすれば上手くいくよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You've got your <kanji>instruction</kanji> and you have your <kanji>practice</kanji>. Time to start your <vocabulary>training</vocabulary>, or simply your <vocabulary>practice</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When I think of that person, my heart aches.
examples.ja: あの人のことを思うと、胸が苦しいんです。

examples.en: I have a mole on my right chest.
examples.ja: 私は右胸にホクロがあります。

examples.en: Why did you get fired? Perhaps you should ask your own conscience about that.
examples.ja: どうして首になったかって？それはご自身の胸に聞いてみてはいかがですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This vocab word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. At least I won't have to bring up the image of you <reading>moon</reading>ing (むね) people with your breasts or whatnot. Oh dang, I just went and did it.

examples.en: Neither CT nor MRI showed any brain problems.
examples.ja: CTでもMRIでも、脳には問題はありませんでした。

examples.en: Did you know that a leech has thirty-two brains?
examples.ja: ヒルには脳が32個もあるって知ってた？

examples.en: You've got to make sure the bacon gets nice and crispy! There have been cases where tapeworms were found in the brains of people who ate it undercooked!
examples.ja: ベーコンはちゃんとカリカリになるまで焼かないと！生焼けで食べた人の脳からサナダムシが発見されたこともあるんだよ！

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Don't have to use your <vocabulary>brain</vocabulary> for that.

examples.en: How do you judge if someone is brain dead?
examples.ja: 脳死かどうかはどうやってジャッジするんですか？

examples.en: For now, try doing this exercise without thinking about it.
examples.ja: とりあえず脳死でこのエクササイズやってみて。

examples.en: Brain hemorrhaging may lead to stroke and, finally, brain death.
examples.ja: 脳内出血は、脳卒中につながり、最悪脳死を引き起こすこともあります。

meaning_mnemonic: If your <kanji>brain</kanji> is <kanji>dead</kanji> you have <vocabulary>brain death</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Try thinking carefully with what little brain you have!
examples.ja: 少ない脳みそを使ってよく考えてみろ！

examples.en: I'm so tired today, my brains just aren't working.
examples.ja: 今日はつかれすぎて脳みそが全然働いていません。

examples.en: I'm not addicted to my smartphone. When the battery runs out and I don't feel like doing anything, I relax by mindlessly scrolling through my phone with zero brain activity.
examples.ja: スマホ中毒じゃないよ。電池切れで何もしたくなくて、脳みそゼロでできるスマホのスクローリングでリラックスしてるんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Do you know みそ Soup and how miso goes in it? This is that miso. It's soft and strange feeling. Now, your <kanji>brain</kanji> <kanji>miso</kanji>, that's your <vocabulary>brains</vocabulary> or your <vocabulary>gray matter</vocabulary>. Essentially, if someone cuts your head open with a katana, this is perhaps what would come out.
reading_mnemonic: Reading is just what you learned with the kanji. Just use your 脳 a bit and it should be easy.

examples.en: That's media brainwashing.
examples.ja: それってメディアの洗脳だよ。

examples.en: They're all brainwashed by the government.
examples.ja: アイツらみんな、政府に洗脳されてるんだよ。

examples.en: The first training you receive after joining Tofugu is brainwashing you into the Tofugu mindset.
examples.ja: トーフグに入社した後、一番最初に受けるトレーニングは、トーフグマインドへの洗脳です。

meaning_mnemonic: Give your <kanji>brain</kanji> a nice <kanji>wash</kanji>. No! Wait! It's not as nice as it sounds. This is <vocabulary>brainwashing</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Who did the graffiti here?
examples.ja: ここに落書きをしたのは誰だ？

examples.en: No, no, no, it's just a doodle.
examples.ja: いやいや、ただの落書きですよ。

examples.en: There used to be lot of graffiti along the underground passages at Shinjuku Station a long time ago, but we rarely see them now.
examples.ja: 新宿駅の地下道には、昔、たくさんの落書きがしてありましたが、今はほとんど見当たりません。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>fall</kanji> into the urge to <kanji>write</kanji>, you just grab whatever's nearby and start <vocabulary>doodling</vocabulary> on it.

落書き means doodling or <vocabulary>scribbling</vocabulary> without much thought, and it also means the scribbles themselves. Imagine a kid doodling in the margins of their notebook in class. <vocabulary>Graffiti</vocabulary> can be 落書き too, but usually this refers to vandalistic graffiti rather than the artistic stuff — think of an "anarchy" symbol under a bridge or a stick figure drawing in a bathroom stall.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 書, however, is kun'yomi in this case and also has rendaku. So just remember that it's read as が for this vocab and you'll be fine.

examples.en: Can you go put a postcard in the mailbox for me?
examples.ja: ポストに葉書を出してきてくれない？

examples.en: There was a handwritten message on the postcard.
examples.ja: その葉書には手書きのメッセージが書かれていました。

examples.en: She always sends a postcard from her trips.
examples.ja: 彼女は毎回、旅行先から葉書を送ってくれます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>writing</kanji> that you put on a <kanji>leaf</kanji> is like something else. Instead of a leaf, think about writing you put on a leafish sized item. A <vocabulary>postcard</vocabulary> perhaps?
reading_mnemonic: The reading is kind of weird, sorry. The reading for 葉 is the は you know and love. Then, 書 is かき despite not having a き on the end like you'd expect. So, it's weird. It's shortened like a postcard is a shortened letter, I suppose? Technically it is the 書き reading, but keep in mind that 書き gets rendaku'd.

examples.en: Kanji characters have both on reading and kun reading.
examples.ja: 漢字には音読みと訓読みがあります。

examples.en: What was the kun'yomi of this kanji?
examples.ja: この漢字の訓読みって何だったっけ？

examples.en: Oh, this is a kun'yomi? I thought it was an on'yomi.
examples.ja: え、これって訓読みだったの？てっきり音読みだと思ってた。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>instruction</kanji> <kanji>reading</kanji> may not make a lot of sense, but you've heard this word before. Jump to the reading and you'll know what the meaning of this word is.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the word 読み (like 読む) and the reading you learned for 訓 combined, making <reading>くんよ</reading>み. Sounds familiar? It's that <vocabulary>kun'yomi</vocabulary> reading you've heard so much about.

examples.en: It was a good lesson.
examples.ja: いい教訓になりました。

examples.en: I will not let this lesson be wasted.
examples.ja: この教訓をムダにはしません。

examples.en: I hope to learn from the lessons learned this time and do better next time.
examples.ja: 今回の教訓を活かして、次回はもっと上手くやれるようにしたいと思います。

meaning_mnemonic: At least way back in the day, things that <kanji>teach</kanji> <kanji>instructions</kanji> to people are things that teach a <vocabulary>lesson</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>moral</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>teachings</vocabulary>. Back in the day, lots of learning was done through storytelling, and storytelling taught lessons and morals, thus, this word.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I still can't forgive him.
examples.ja: 彼のこと、まだ許すことはできないよ。

examples.en: Who said such awful things? It is unforgivable!
examples.ja: 誰がそんなヒドイこと言ったの？許せない！

examples.en: Ladies and gentlemen, please forgive me. I just farted in this car.
examples.ja: みなさん、どうかお許しください。今この車の中でオナラをしてしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>permit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to permit</vocabulary>. It also means <vocabulary>to forgive</vocabulary>, in that "I'll permit it this time... but only this time." Look out for 許さない in TV shows, too. It means "I won't permit this!" or "I won't forgive you!"
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to allow it. <reading>You're</reading> (ゆる) allowed to do it this one time, okay?

examples.en: He is my friend.
examples.ja: 彼は私の友達です。

examples.en: If you don't mind, would you like to be my friend?
examples.ja: よかったら、私と友達になってくれませんか？

examples.en: I heard from a friend of a friend that Viet is a yakuza!
examples.ja: 友達の友達から聞いたことなんだけど、ビエトってヤクザらしいよ！

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>friend</kanji> that you <kanji>attain</kanji> is your <vocabulary>friend</vocabulary>. This is the most common way to say "friend," so learn it if you want to make any!
reading_mnemonic: The readings for both of these are readings you haven't learned yet, though maybe you already know this word since it's fairly common. Think of it this way. You have your friend <reading>Tom</reading> (とも) Cruise. You like him, and he likes you. You're close enough friends that you can <reading>touch</reading> (だち) each other too. Like, on the shoulder or on the hand or whatever, without it being awkward. So, you like to <reading>Tom touch</reading> (ともだち) when you can, because he has nice skin.

examples.en: My daddy is a pizza delivery driver. He can deliver pizzas faster than anybody else.
examples.ja: 僕のお父さんはピザの配達人です。誰よりも速くピザを配達することができます。

examples.en: Koichi pounded his chest with a fist, saying he would definitely deliver it by six.
examples.ja: コウイチは、ゼッタイに六時までに配達してみせると言って、胸をたたきました。

examples.en: It completely slipped my mind that I have to deliver this flower today.
examples.ja: この花を今日中に配達しなければいけないのを、すっかり忘れていました。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>distribute</kanji> the goods, they <kanji>attain</kanji> the goods. You are going <vocabulary>to deliver</vocabulary> to everyone.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My mother's cooking is delicious to the level of a culinary master.
