meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji> who has "<kanji>attain</kanji>ed" is someone who knows much. They are a <vocabulary>master</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>expert</vocabulary>, obviously.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Due to a miscommunication, we ended up with a pink car.
examples.ja: 伝達ミスで、ピンクの車になってしまったんです。

examples.en: I'm worried about whether what I wanted to say was conveyed properly.
examples.ja: 伝えたかったことが、ちゃんと伝達されたのか心配です。

examples.en: I’m researching the neural signal transmissions that occur while people are learning a new language.
examples.ja: 私は、人々が新しい言語を学んでいる時の、ニューロンの信号伝達について研究しています。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>transmit</kanji> something and you <kanji>attain</kanji> it on the other end, you've done a <vocabulary>transmission</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It is quiet today, isn't it?
examples.ja: 今日は静かですね。

examples.en: Excuse me, could you please be a little more quiet?
examples.ja: すみませんが、もう少し静かにしていただけますか？

examples.en: With Koichi and Viet on board, the cab quietly started to move.
examples.ja: コウイチとビエトを乗せて、そのタクシーは静かに動き出した。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the な adjective form of <kanji>quiet</kanji>, which is kind of just like the noun, anyways. What is the adjective version of quiet? It's also <vocabulary>quiet</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to be <vocabulary>quiet</vocabulary>. <reading>She's</reading> (しず) being nice and quiet, unlike you!

examples.en: First, I'll upload a still image.
examples.ja: まずは静止画をアップします。

examples.en: My cat stands still when I point the camera at her.
examples.ja: ウチの猫はカメラを向けると静止します。

examples.en: After hitting a home run, the batter always pauses just for a moment, right?
examples.ja: ホームランを打ち上げた後、バッターってゼッタイちょこっと静止するよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Everything is <kanji>quiet</kanji> and <kanji>stop</kanji>ped. The world is <vocabulary>still</vocabulary> and everything is <vocabulary>at rest</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am not sure I can keep my composure when so many cute cats are around.
examples.ja: こんなにカワイイ猫たちがいっぱいだと、平静を保てる自信がありません。

examples.en: I find it hard to stay calm in front of someone I like.
examples.ja: 私、好きな人の前では、平静でいられなくなるんです。

examples.en: She was panicking, unable to stop at the red light, but regained her inner calm by listening to the radio.
examples.ja: 彼女は赤信号で止まれずにパニックに落ちいっていたが、ラジオを聞きながら心の平静を取りもどした。

meaning_mnemonic: A place that is <kanji>peace</kanji> and <kanji>quiet</kanji> is a very <vocabulary>calm</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>serene</vocabulary> place. Ahh, so nice!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He is the hope of all mankind.
examples.ja: 彼は全人類の希望です。

examples.en: We, humanity, learn something new and grow every day.
examples.ja: 私たち人類は、日々新しいことを学び、成長します。

examples.en: I believe that humanity is harmful to the Earth.
examples.ja: 私、地球にとって、人類は悪だと思うんです。

meaning_mnemonic: There's only one <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>type</kanji> and that is <vocabulary>mankind</vocabulary>, otherwise known as <vocabulary>humanity</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>humankind</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: With this application, files can be quickly categorized.
examples.ja: このアプリを使えば、すぐにファイルが分類できます。

examples.en: In this library, books are classified by genre.
examples.ja: この図書館では、本はジャンル別に分類されています。

examples.en: E-mails are automatically sorted by category.
examples.ja: 電子メールは、カテゴリーごとに自動的に分類されます。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>divide</kanji> something into different <kanji>type</kanji>s. That's called <vocabulary>classification</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>categorization</vocabulary>.

分類 is a relatively formal word that refers to the act of classifying or categorizing items, organisms, or information into specific groups based on shared characteristics or criteria.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My dog is on two different medications.
examples.ja: うちの犬は二種類の薬を飲んでいます。

examples.en: How many kinds are there in all?
examples.ja: 全部で何種類あるの？

examples.en: There are so many kinds that it is hard to decide.
examples.ja: 種類が多すぎて中々決められません。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>kind</kanji> and <kanji>type</kanji> is the <vocabulary>kind</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>type</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>sort</vocabulary>. Basically, if you know the meaning of either of these kanji you'll know the meaning of this word as well, since they all share nicely.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That is my relative's company.
examples.ja: それ、親類の会社なんです。

examples.en: I do not have a single relative.
examples.ja: 私には一人も親類がいません。

examples.en: I received a phone call from a relative in Australia.
examples.ja: オーストラリアにいる親類から電話がかかってきました。

meaning_mnemonic: These people are kind of like a <kanji>type</kanji> of <kanji>parents</kanji>. Not quite parents, but kind of, in a pinch anyways. These are your <vocabulary>relatives</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Just follow the instructions and you'll be fine.
examples.ja: 説明書通りにやれば大丈夫ですよ。

examples.en: The instructions for the ice cream maker I bought yesterday were missing.
examples.ja: 昨日買ったアイスクリームメーカーに説明書がついていませんでした。

examples.en: When you play a new game, are you the type of person who reads the instructions first or do you start playing without reading them?
examples.ja: 新しいゲームをする時に説明書を読んでから始めるタイプですか。それとも、説明書は読まずにいきなり始めるタイプですか。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 説明 means "explanation"? Take that explanation and <kanji>write</kanji> it down. Now you have an <vocabulary>instruction manual</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>user guide</vocabulary>.

This is the booklet or sheet of paper that comes with appliances, electronics, or flat-pack furniture — the thing that explains how to use the product.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Excuse me, how often do the steam trains come?
examples.ja: すみません。汽車は何分おきに来ますか？

examples.en: I took a steam train in England.
examples.ja: イングランドで汽車に乗りました。

examples.en: The smoke from the steam train stung my eyes.
examples.ja: 汽車の煙が目にしみました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>steam</kanji> <kanji>car</kanji> is a car that runs on steam. No regular car runs on steam, but what thing that has things called "cars" does run on steam? How about a <vocabulary>steam train</vocabulary>? You can also think about 電車s, which are electric cars (but means "train"). This is similar to that, but now it's run with steam, making it a steam train.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It is a state-owned steamboat company.
examples.ja: それは国有の汽船会社です。

examples.en: This building is located near the Kanmon Steamship Terminal.
examples.ja: この建物は関門汽船乗り場の近くにあります。

examples.en: I enjoy leisurely traveling by steamship, slowly making my way across the sea. This summer, I rented out an entire steamship and traveled to Singapore.
examples.ja: 私は汽船で時間をかけてゆっくり海を進むのが好きなんです。今年の夏は汽船を一台借り切って、シンガポールへ行きました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>steam</kanji> <kanji>ship</kanji> is a <vocabulary>steam ship</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>steam boat</vocabulary>. So fancy back in their day!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What is the document for?
examples.ja: それは何の書類ですか？

examples.en: Could you please photocopy this document for me?
examples.ja: この書類、コピーしておいてもらえるかな？

examples.en: Please do not lose this important document.
examples.ja: 大事な書類なので、ゼッタイに無くさないでくださいね。

meaning_mnemonic: If you put <kanji>writing</kanji> into a <kanji>category</kanji>, you'd have to write it down after you've chosen what category it is in. Where would you write that down? Into a <vocabulary>document</vocabulary>, probably.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I attend cooking classes on Tuesday nights.
examples.ja: 火曜日の夜に、料理教室に通っています。

examples.en: Sorry, but I have plans for next Monday and Tuesday.
examples.ja: すみませんが、来週の月曜日と火曜日は予定があるんです。

examples.en: I got owned in baseball on Tuesday.
examples.ja: 火曜日は野球でコテンパにやられたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>fire</kanji> day of the week is the day after the worst day of the week (monday). You set fire to everything because you're so pissed off about yesterday, which makes today <vocabulary>Tuesday</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

examples.en: Finally, it is Friday.
examples.ja: ようやく金曜日です。

examples.en: I think it will be ready by Friday afternoon.
examples.ja: 金曜日の午後までにはできていると思います。

examples.en: You haven't forgotten that we planned to go out for drinks Friday night, have you?
examples.ja: 金曜日に飲みに行く約束、忘れてないよね？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>gold</kanji> day of the week is the greatest day. It's the day that makes you feel like gold because it's the end of the weekdays and the beginning of the weekend! This day is <vocabulary>Friday</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

examples.en: Is it possible to make a reservation for three people at seven o'clock on a Friday night?
examples.ja: 金曜の夜の七時に三人で予約って可能ですか？

examples.en: If possible, I would like to order an illustration of my dog!
examples.ja: もし可能なら、ウチのワンコのイラストをお願いしたいです！

examples.en: If it's okay for a delivery tomorrow afternoon, I think it's possible.
examples.ja: 明日の午後のデリバリーでよければ、可能だと思います。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>ability</kanji> is there, so it is <kanji>possible</kanji>... wait, there's enough ability to make this <vocabulary>possible</vocabulary>? Let's do it!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This lid doesn't close properly.
examples.ja: このフタ、うまく閉まらないんだけど。

examples.en: What time was it that the store closes?
examples.ja: あのお店、何時に閉まるんだっけ？

examples.en: Suddenly, the door closed by itself.
examples.ja: 急に、とびらがひとりでに閉まりました。

examples.en: Shoot, it's locked!
examples.ja: げ、カギが閉まってる！

meaning_mnemonic: If 閉める is "to close something" or "to shut something," then this is going to be the version where you don't do anything and something closes on its own. That's why this is <vocabulary>to close</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to shut</vocabulary>. You remember this because the door keeps shutting on your hand, <reading>marr</reading>ing (まる) it over and over again. Ouch.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 閉める.

examples.en: "Achoo!" "Are you all right?"
examples.ja: 「ハックション！」「大丈夫？」

examples.en: It's not okay at all.
examples.ja: 全然大丈夫じゃないです。

examples.en: Is this sun screen safe for babies?
examples.ja: この日焼け止めは、赤ちゃんに使っても大丈夫ですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>height</kanji> of your <kanji>husband</kanji> makes everything <vocabulary>safe</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>all right</vocabulary>. Nothing you need to worry about when you have your super giant husband around to protect you. This is a really useful word, and it is used all the time. If someone asks: "Are you alright?" you could say in response "大丈夫" to mean you're doing all right.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: I have ten tickets for the soccer game on Sunday.
examples.ja: 日曜日のサッカーの試合のチケットを十枚持っています。

examples.en: My breakfast is usually just one slice of toast.
examples.ja: いつもは朝ご飯は食パン一枚だけです。

examples.en: I’d like to buy some Tofugu stickers. How much would one be?
examples.ja: トーフグのステッカーを何枚か買いたいのですが、一枚いくらになりますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, so this is <vocabulary>flat object counter</vocabulary>.

This counter can be used with various "flat" things, such as <vocabulary>clothing items</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>sheets</vocabulary>, paper, stamps, dishes, and more. Notice how they're all kind of flat shaped?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Hey! That's not a place to sit.
examples.ja: ちょっと！そこ、座るとこじゃないよ。

examples.en: Could you not sit on the important documents?
examples.ja: 大事な書類の上に座らないでもらえますか。

examples.en: Are you okay? Would you like to sit on this chair?
examples.ja: 大丈夫？よかったら、このイスに座る？

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to sit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is unlike the kanji reading, so let's use a separate mnemonic to remember this. Just imagine yourself going <vocabulary>to sit</vocabulary> down. You sit down, and the ground collapses below you and you fall. When you land, you find yourself in a nasty, stinking <reading>sewer</reading> (すわ). It is so gross. Taste the sewage in your mouth. Smell it. Feel gross. You shouldn't have sat down on that spot, it was looking awfully dangerous, now that you think about it.

examples.en: I wonder where Koichi and the others went.
examples.ja: コウイチ達、一体どこに行ったんだろう。

examples.en: Students were partying every day.
examples.ja: 学生達は毎日パーティーばかりしていました。

examples.en: Aren’t you still minors?
examples.ja: あなた達はまだ未成年でしょう。

meaning_mnemonic:
You'll see this attached to other words to make them <kanji>plural</kanji>. That's why it's called a <vocabulary>pluralizing suffix</vocabulary>. 

Note that you can only attach this to people and animals to make them plural. It can also be used with a person's name, like マリアたち. In that case, it refers to Maria and the group of people she's with! This might sound a little complicated, but you'll get the hang of it with a little practice!
reading_mnemonic:
This is almost the same reading you learned with the kanji. Remember たつ? Well this is read たち. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

If you want to pluralize something, <reading>touch</reading> (たち) it to something else. One friend touches another friend, well now they're friends. Plural friends! All thanks to the good ol' pluralizing suffix touch!

Oh, and don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached in front of this word.

examples.en: I got some kind of warning message... what should I do?
examples.ja: なんか警告文が出てきたんだけど…どうしよう？

examples.en: I advised him that he should pay back the money he borrowed soon.
examples.ja: 借りた金を早く返すよう警告した。

examples.en: That player gets a yellow card warning in every game.
examples.ja: あの選手はどの試合でも必ず警告のイエローカードを出されるね。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>announce</kanji> something to <kanji>warn</kanji> somebody, you're <vocabulary>warning</vocabulary> them. Sometimes you're just trying to give them some helpful <vocabulary>advice</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I think the pudding will finally harden soon.
examples.ja: そろそろプリンが固まるころかな。

examples.en: My decision to quit Tofugu finally solidified.
examples.ja: ようやくトーフグをやめる決心が固まりました。

examples.en: Why are you guys packed into the corner like this?
examples.ja: みんな、なんでそんなすみっこに固まってるの？

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen how 固める means "to make hard." This word means that something hardened by itself, it means <vocabulary>to harden</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to solidify</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: Bitcoin will reach one million dollars within a decade.
examples.ja: ビットコインは十年以内に100万ドルに達するでしょう。

examples.en: Only a little longer until we attain the target number of people.
examples.ja: 目標人数に達するまで、あと少しです！

examples.en: I heard that at WaniKani, when you reach a certain level, Koichi’s karaoke video is played. I wonder if it's true.
examples.ja: ワニカニでは、あるレベルに達するとコウイチのカラオケ動画が流れるらしい。本当かな？

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 達 means <kanji>attain</kanji>. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means <vocabulary>to attain</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This reading for this is a bit of an exception. You know the reading for 達 is たつ, but here it's shortened, to just たっ. So make sure you remember.

examples.en: I'm not wearing glasses right now, so I can't see far away objects very well.
examples.ja: 今はメガネをかけてないので、遠くの物がよく見えません。

examples.en: I live far away from my family.
examples.ja: 私は家族から遠くはなれて住んでいます。

examples.en: The soldier walked at a brisk pace thinking about how long distances feel much longer without any companions.
examples.ja: 仲間がいないといつもの道が遠く感じると思いながら、兵士は足早に歩いた。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun/no-adjective version of the kanji <kanji>far</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>far away</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>distant</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi reading which you learned with 遠い. How convenient!

examples.en: This is a Japanese lullaby.
examples.ja: これは日本の子守歌です。

examples.en: What's the most popular lullaby in America?
examples.ja: アメリカで一番有名な子守歌は何ですか？

examples.en: That's a lullaby my mother often sang to me when I was a child.
examples.ja: 子供のころ、母によく歌ってもらった子守歌なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>song</kanji> you sing to <kanji>protect</kanji> your <kanji>child</kanji> while they sleep is called a <vocabulary>lullaby</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The readings for this word are all kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 守 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you finish singing a <vocabulary>lullaby</vocabulary> to your child they always ask for <reading>more</reading> (もり). It doesn't matter how many you sing, they always want at least one more before they will fall asleep.

examples.en: Please tell me about higher education in your country.
examples.ja: あなたの国の高等教育について教えてください。

examples.en: My son is still in elementary school, but he is already studying higher level math.
examples.ja: うちの息子はまだ小学生ですが、すでに高等レベルの数学を勉強しています。

examples.en: Programming this robot requires advanced skills.
examples.ja: このロボットのプログラミングには、高等な技術が必要です。

meaning_mnemonic: When you are <kanji>high</kanji>er than <kanji>equal</kanji>, you are above the very top, you are above everyone. You are <vocabulary>high class</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The dictionary form of "ate" is "eat."
examples.ja: 「食べた」の辞書形は「食べる」です。

examples.en: I'm fine with dictionary form, but I have trouble with conjugated form.
examples.ja: 辞書形は分かるんですが、活用形がよく分かりません。

examples.en: Write the dictionary form of this word. You may use a dictionary if you do not know it.
examples.ja: この言葉の辞書形を書きなさい。分からなければ辞書を使ってもかまいません。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a combination of the word 辞書 "dictionary" and the suffix 〜形 or "form." Put them together and you get <vocabulary>dictionary form</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I would like to maintain an equal relationship with my husband.
examples.ja: 私は夫と対等な関係でありたいと思っています。

examples.en: My son is only six years old, but he can already talk to adults on equal terms.
examples.ja: ウチの子はまだ六才ですが、もう大人と対等に話せます。

examples.en: It is only recently that women have been able to work on an equal footing with men.
examples.ja: 女性が男性と対等な立場で働けるようになったのは、ここ最近のことです。

meaning_mnemonic: It doesn't matter what you say <kanji>versus</kanji> <kanji>equal</kanji> rights. If you really want things to be <vocabulary>equal</vocabulary>, you have to support <vocabulary>equality</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Luckily, an empty taxi just came.
examples.ja: 幸いなことに、ちょうど空車のタクシーがやって来ました。

examples.en: I'm happy that I was able to help you.
examples.ja: お役に立てたようで、幸いです。

examples.en: Fortunately, there were no injuries.
examples.ja: 幸いケガはありませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Happiness</kanji> is <vocabulary>happiness</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If your life is filled with nothing but <vocabulary>happiness</vocabulary>, every time someone says something to you, all you can do is say, "<reading>Sigh, wha</reading>t (さいわ)?" You sigh and say what. Because you're too happy to really listen. You're just sighing all day and not paying attention.

examples.en: Entry is prohibited to all but related parties.
examples.ja: 関係者以外の立ち入りを禁じる。

examples.en: I think alcohol should be banned worldwide.
examples.ja: アルコールは世界で禁じられるべきだと思います。

examples.en: Private conversation is prohibited in this room.
examples.ja: この部屋では、私語を禁じます。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>prohibition</kanji> so the verb version means <vocabulary>to prohibit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to forbid</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: There are almost no goods in the grocery store around this time.
examples.ja: この時間のスーパーには品物がほとんどありません。

examples.en: The store's showcases were filled with many items.
examples.ja: そのお店のショーケースにはたくさんの品物がならんでいました。

examples.en: Sorry, this item has already been reserved.
examples.ja: すいません、こちらの品物はすでにご予約をいただいている物なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>product</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is any type of general <vocabulary>goods</vocabulary>. It's about as specific as you can get when you're talking about <vocabulary>thing</vocabulary>s like this.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You've seen those readings before, but the one for 品 (しな) is a little tricky, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

Think of the <reading>sheen</reading> (しな) that new <vocabulary>goods</vocabulary> have before you buy them. When you bring them home, that sheen is already gone. But then you go back to the store and, wow! All the goods you don't already own have that sheen! Gotta buy them!

examples.en: Cats purr with their throats.
examples.ja: 猫は、喉でゴロゴロという音を出します。

examples.en: My throat feels irritated.
examples.ja: なんか喉がイガイガする。

examples.en: I have a sore throat. Can you sing on my behalf?
examples.ja: 喉が痛いので、私の代わりに歌ってくれませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji (and is a body part) it uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Remember the mnemonic from when you first learned this kanji? Well こういち is still in your <kanji>throat</kanji> and he doesn't want to get out. In fact, every time you tug on him, he shouts, "<reading>No Do</reading>- (のど)" but you gag and can't hear the rest. People around you think you're saying "No Do-" but it's really just the weirdo living in your throat now. What a pain...

examples.en: That man is an otolaryngologist.
examples.ja: あの方は耳鼻喉頭科の先生です。

examples.en: Laryngeal cancer is often caused by alcohol and tobacco.
examples.ja: 喉頭ガンは酒やタバコが原因で起こることが多い。

examples.en: He underwent laryngeal surgery, but lost his voice and was given an artificial larynx.
examples.ja: 彼は喉頭手術を受けましたが、声を失い、人工喉頭となりました。

meaning_mnemonic: The body part that lives between your <kanji>throat</kanji> and your <kanji>head</kanji> is your <vocabulary>larynx</vocabulary>. Otherwise known as the <vocabulary>voice box</vocabulary>, because your vocal cords live in there.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned 頭's on'yomi reading with 頭部, but here's a mnemonic in case you forgot:

If you really want to get a <vocabulary>larynx</vocabulary> workout, go to <reading>とう</reading>きょう. It's loud, it's crowded, and you have to yell the entire time to get people to hear what you have to say. You also know 18 levels of kanji and you really want to shout them all out, which makes your <vocabulary>voice box</vocabulary> tired (but makes you happy).

examples.en: He plays the drums well.
examples.ja: 彼はドラムを叩くのが上手い。

examples.en: I told you to knock on the door before opening it, didn't I?!
examples.ja: 開ける前に、ドアを叩いてって言ったよね！？

examples.en: I'm not particularly fond of Japanese manzai comedy, where they hit people on the head to deliver punchlines. Wasn't it taught in school that you shouldn't hit others?
examples.ja: 日本のマンザイは、人の頭を叩いてツッコムのであまり好きではありません。人のことを叩いちゃいけないって学校で習わなかったのかな？

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tap</kanji> or <kanji>strike</kanji>, and the verb version is <vocabulary>to strike</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to tap</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to hit</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to knock</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to beat</vocabulary>.

This verb can be used for both things and people, and the English translation will change depending on what it is you're striking. You'll always have some kind of object, though, since this is a transitive verb. So you might tap someone on the shoulder, knock at a door, or beat a drum.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you already know this reading from when you learned the kanji!

examples.en: Please give me a hard candy.
examples.ja: 飴を一つ下さい。

examples.en: Is it true that there are curry-flavored hard candies in Japan?
examples.ja: 日本にはカレー味の飴があるって本当ですか？

examples.en: Can you go to the pharmacy and get me some lozenges for my throat?
examples.ja: ドラッグストアでノド飴を買ってきてくれませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. When we talk about this kind of <vocabulary>candy</vocabulary>, it's usually <vocabulary>hard candy</vocabulary> 🍬 or a <vocabulary>lollipop</vocabulary> 🍭 though.
reading_mnemonic: This word is made up of a single kanji, and it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

examples.en: My father is a master of sugar sculptures.
examples.ja: 私の父は飴細工の名人です。

examples.en: Have you ever made sugar sculptures?
examples.ja: 飴細工作ったことある？

examples.en: Apparently, the sugar goldfish is similar to real goldfish in shape and taste.
examples.ja: その金魚の飴細工は、形も味も本物の金魚にそっくりなんだって。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Candy</kanji> made into a <kanji>thin</kanji> <kanji>construction</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sugar sculpture</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>candy sculpture</vocabulary>. It's usually a <vocabulary>sugar animal</vocabulary>, but it can be anything, really.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi reading for the first kanji and the on'yomi readings for the second two. You haven't learned this reading for 工 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You want your <vocabulary>sugar sculptures</vocabulary> to be made into <reading>coo</reading>kies (く)! Cookies are your other favorite snack, so having a cookie that's really just entirely made of sugar is the absolute best.

Also, watch out for the rendaku on 細, it's easy to miss if you're focusing on remembering this new on'yomi reading.

examples.en: Your disease will most definitely be cured.
examples.ja: お前の病気は必ず治る。

examples.en: His injuries have healed, but the scars remain.
examples.ja: ケガは治ったが、キズが残った。

examples.en: Do you know the saying "stupidity can never be cured"?
examples.ja: 「バカは一生治らない」っていうことわざ知ってる？

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji 治 means <kanji>cure</kanji>, but this verb refers to the natural process of getting better: <vocabulary>to get better</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to get well</vocabulary>, or simply <vocabulary>to heal</vocabulary>. This is an intransitive verb, meaning that it happens on its own. Nobody cures you, you just get better.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

When you get sick, your mom calls every day to ask, "Are you better <reading>now</reading> (なお)?" How about NOW!? How about NOW!? Jeez Mom, just let me rest!

examples.en: Kyoko picks on me.
examples.ja: 今日子ちゃんが私を苛めるの。

examples.en: Stop bullying Koichi!
examples.ja: コウイチを苛めるな！

examples.en: My elder sister always sticks up for other children if they're being bullied.
examples.ja: 姉は、他の子が苛められていたら、いつも助けてあげるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>frustration</kanji>. What do frustrated people do? They tend <vocabulary>to bully</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to pick on</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to tease</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to torment</vocabulary> other people.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: This is a huge problem related to people's everyday lives.
examples.ja: これは人々の生活に関わる大問題だ。

examples.en: I have been involved in many projects, but this one is the most exciting.
examples.ja: 今まで色々なプロジェクトに関わってきましたが、今回のプロジェクトが一番ワクワクします。

examples.en: Allergies are not to be taken lightly. They can be life-threatening!
examples.ja: アレルギーは軽く見たらダメだよ。命に関わることもあるんだから！

meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji means <kanji>related</kanji>. As a verb, this often means <vocabulary>to be involved</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be related</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to be connected</vocabulary>. Basically, things that have to do with being related to something else.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  

Ever heard of the "<reading>Kaw Kaw</reading> (かか) Crow Gang"? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and squawking "kaw kaw" ... You don't want <vocabulary>to be involved</vocabulary> with them.

examples.en: What was it like the first time you fell in love?
examples.ja: あなたの初恋ってどんな感じだった？

examples.en: My first love's name was...I think...Micchan.
examples.ja: 初恋の人の名前は…たしか、ミッちゃんだったかな。

examples.en: Grandpa, when was the first time you fell in love?
examples.ja: おじいちゃん、おじいちゃんが初恋をしたのっていつ？

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>first</kanji> <kanji>love</kanji> is your <vocabulary>first love</vocabulary> or your <vocabulary>first crush</vocabulary>. This usually refers to the first time you fall in love, but it can also refer to the person you fall in love with.
reading_mnemonic: Similarly to 初耳, 初 behaves more like a prefix here, which means that this uses kun'yomi readings. You already know these for both 初 and 恋, so you should be good to go!

examples.en: Oh man, I'm so nervous.
examples.ja: やばい、めっちゃドキドキする。

examples.en: He was so cool that my heart was pounding.
examples.ja: カッコよくて、ドキドキでした。

examples.en: I could feel your excitement.
examples.ja: ドキドキが伝わってきたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Doc, Doc</reading> (ドキドキ), listen to my <vocabulary>racing heart</vocabulary>. I'm so <vocabulary>excited</vocabulary>, but I'm also a bit <vocabulary>nervous</vocabulary>.

ドキドキ is an オノマトペ used to describe the feeling of your heart beating fast. When does your heart race? When you get excited or nervous, so ドキドキ also expresses those feelings!

examples.en: It took an hour to get connected to the internet.
examples.ja: インターネットが繋がるのに一時間かかった。

examples.en: All failures lead to success.
examples.ja: 全ての失敗が成功に繋がるんだよ。

examples.en: Koichi and I are not related by blood.
examples.ja: コウイチと私は血が繋がってません。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>connect</kanji>, which makes this <vocabulary>to be connected to</vocabulary>. In other situations, this can also mean <vocabulary>to be tied together</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to lead to</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You already learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go!
